tossups.question: The defending side in this battle would execute a nearly identical strike one year later in the Battle of Rabaul with similar results. The Commander in Chief of the Combined Fleet had intended for a declaration of war to be delivered before this battle, but due to decryption issues, it actually arrived one hour late. One side issued the 14 part message before this battle. In this battle, one side used the phrase, (*) Tora, Tora, Tora. The attacking force was commanded by Isoroku Yamamoto in this battle. The USS Oklahoma and USS Arizona were damaged during this battle. This battle was a "day that will live in infamy." For 10 points, name this attack on Hawaii, after which the US officially declared war on Japan.
tossups.answer: Raid on Pearl Harbor

tossups.question: In this play, one character believes that she sees her estranged husband in a migration diorama. One character in this play is arrested in Prospect Park in the middle of a fantasy about being in Antarctica with Mr. Lies. A character in this play who repeats the phrase "the Great Work begins" is attended to by Belize. In this play, Hannah volunteers at the Mormon Visitor's Center with the valium-addicted Harper. One character in this play falsely claims that he has (*) liver cancer. In this play, Louis Ironson leaves the terminally ill Prior Walter for Joe Pitt. This play includes the sections Millennium Approaches and Perestroika. For 10 points, a fictionalized version of Roy Cohn dies from AIDS in what "Gay Fantasia on National Themes" by Tony Kushner?
tossups.answer: Angels in America: A Gay Fantasia on National Themes [antiprompt on Perestroika or Millennium Approaches until mentioned]

tossups.question: A group of compounds that do not fully undergo this process are known as IDPs and include SUMO-1. One compound that assists in this process has apical, equatorial, and intermediate domains; that compound is GroEL. This process occurs down a funnel in the energy landscape theory of this process. The hydrophobic interactions of this process are promoted by Hsp60 and other (*) chaperonins. During this process, PDI catalyzes the formation of "bridges" between thiol groups. Early stages of this process create beta sheets and alpha helices, which are examples of secondary structure. Errors in this process can result in prions. For 10 points, name this process in which a linear polypeptide adopts a three-dimensional conformation.
tossups.answer: protein folding [accept polypeptide folding; prompt on formation of tertiary structure or secondary structure by asking, "which occurs during what general process?"] [IDPs are intrinsically disordered proteins; PDI stands for protein disulfide isomerase]

tossups.question: A person with this title is put on trial for the murder of Chin the Conqueror, which had been committed centuries earlier by another holder of this title. It's not the Dalai Lama, but people with this title are selected through a process which involves selecting the toys of previous holders of this title. A character with this title regains her memory after experiencing the memories of the first holder of this title named (*) Wan. Another character with this title is nearly killed after being struck with lightning in the episode "The Crossroads of Destiny." Holders of this title include Kyoshi and Roku. The most notable holder of this title is found in an iceberg at the beginning of the series in which he appears by Katara and Sokka. For 10 points, Korra and Aang hold what title, which allows them to bend all four elements?
tossups.answer: the Avatar

tossups.question: In Aesop's fables, one of these creatures ended his companionship with a man because he blew hot air to warm his hands and cold air to cool his porridge. In a writing by Ovid, Hera cursed Priapus, and his attempt to rape Lotis was unsuccessful because a donkey belonging to one of these creatures alerted her. Midas took care of one of the creatures who told him that (*) the best thing for a person is to die as quickly as possible, and for that feat Midas was granted a wish. The creator of these creatures attempted to embrace the wood nymph Syrinx who was transformed into reeds, so that creator of these creatures turned her into pipes. One of these creatures was flayed after losing a music contest to Apollo and was named Marsyas [MAR-see-us]. For 10 points, Pan is often represented by what half-goat creatures?
tossups.answer: satyrs [accept satyroi or fauns]

tossups.question: Two alliances in this conflict were created as a result of a conflict about the flying of banners in Donauwörth [DOAN-ow-voort]. In a lead-up to this conflict, a group of Croatian soldiers turned to piracy in the Uskok War. Ottavio Piccolomini plotted the assassination of one leader during this war at the urging of Ferdinand II. This war's Battle of Rain saw one leader ford the River Lech. Albrecht von (*) Wallenstein led one side to victory at this war's fog-ridden Battle of Lützen. This war's Bohemian phase ended at the Battle of White Mountain, which saw a victory for Count Tilly. This war began after the second defenestration of Prague. This war was ended by the Peace of Westphalia. For 10 points, name this war between Catholics and Protestants from 1618 to 1648.
tossups.answer: Thirty Years' War

tossups.question: At the beginning of one story, a character with this surname visits the narrator's house and asks to see the bees in his backyard. An author with this surname notes that "No Nightingale did ever chaunt / More welcome notes" than the title character of one poem. A poet with first name "Black" and this surname resides on Miguel Street in a V.S. Naipaul story. A poem by an author with this surname describes music which "in my heart I bore / Long after it was heard no more," sung by a (*) "solitary highland lass." A poem by an author with this surname, which may have been plagiarized from his sister Dorothy, describes flowers which "flash upon that inward eye / Which is the bliss of solitude." For 10 points, give this surname of the poet of "The Solitary Reaper" and "I Wandered Lonely As A Cloud," the latter of which describes "a host of golden daffodils."
tossups.answer: Wordsworth [accept Black Wordsworth or B. Wordsworth, accept William Wordsworth, accept White Wordsworth, probably accept Dorothy Wordsworth too I guess]

tossups.question: A group named for this property consists of all 2 by 2 matrices with determinant 1. First-order ODEs with this property can be solved via multiplication by an integrating factor. The simplex algorithm can only be applied when both the system of constraints and objective function have this property. Non-pathological solutions to Cauchy's functional equation have this property. A function with this property is constructed to (*) approximate the root of a function in Newton's method. Cramer's rule is used to solve systems of equations with this property. The derivative of a function with this property is constant. For 10 points, name this property of functions that can be written in slope-intercept form, like y equals x plus one.
tossups.answer: linearity [accept special linear group; accept answers like it's just a line]

tossups.question: One artist from this country painted large watercolors such as his Fish Series before switching to producing works called "poster-portraits." Another artist from this country took part of a work from that artist and surrounded it with the all-caps words "ERR," "DIE," "HUG," and "EAT." One painting from this country contains the word "BILL," written in red and in capitals. The poem "The Great Figure" inspired a painting from this country about a (*) fire truck which included three of the title number arranged within each other. This country's Precisionist art movement created such paintings as I Saw The Figure Five in Gold, by Charles Demuth [DEEM-uth]. For 10 points, name this country home to Georgia O'Keeffe, some of whose paintings are displayed at this country's Met Museum in New York City.
tossups.answer: United States of America [or USA or America] [All the clues are Demuth except the second line, which is Robert Indiana, and the last line]

tossups.question: Ernest Sosa's AAA model of this field probably does not accommodate fake barn cases. It's not metaphysics, but David Hume established a dichotomy in this field by proposing his namesake fork. A three-page paper in this field described a job applicant with ten coins in his pocket in criticism of a common assertion in this field. The main character of the (*) Theaetetus [thee-ih-TEE-tuss] attempts to define a central concept of this field as perception. Edmund Gettier critiqued the "justified true belief" definition of this field's central concept. Skeptics may claim that the central concept of this field is impossible to obtain. For 10 points, name this philosophical discipline that studies knowledge.
tossups.answer: epistemology [prompt on philosophy of knowledge until "knowledge" is read; prompt clowns who buzz in with philosophy before "philosophical" is read]

tossups.question: One of this ruler's advisors adopted him from a hunter who had bought him from cowherds. Legendarily, this ruler was woken up by a large lion licking his face, as recorded by the historian Justin. Elephants given by this ruler in a peace treaty were critical at the Battle of Ipsus. This ruler's court included the ambassador (*) Megasthenes. Bhadrabahu predicted a famine during the rule of this king, leading him to fast to death as a Jain monk. This ruler ended a war with Seleucus I Nicator [suh-LYOO-kus one nye-KAY-ter] by marrying his daughter. This ruler's mentor Chanakya is traditionally claimed to have written the Arthashastra. This ruler defeated the Nandas on his way to establishing the first empire to rule most of the Indian subcontinent. For 10 points, name this founder of the Mauryan Empire.
tossups.answer: Chandragupta Maurya

tossups.question: In this work, a very poor character spends his savings on Viennese coffee only to shatter the glass out of nerves and run away. In this novel, the doctor of the recently deposed president is killed for refusing to say the president was a suicidal drunk. A character in this novel runs for political office using the slogan "those who have always won will win again." One character in this novel works in a (*) mine to earn enough money to marry his fiance before owning the Tres Marías hacienda. In this novel, Pedro Tercero is the father of the protagonist Alba. This novel opens with the accidental poisoning of the green-haired Rosa the Beautiful, which was earlier predicted by the psychic Clara Del Valle. For 10 points, name this magical realist novel about the Trueba family, which was written by Isabel Allende.
tossups.answer: The House of the Spirits [or La casa de los espiritus]

tossups.question: The derivative of this quantity appears in the left-hand side of the Cauchy momentum equation. The path integral of this quantity around a closed loop equals 0 according to Kelvin's circulation theorem. Fluid flow is incompressible if the divergence of this quantity is 0. This quantity, density, and a characteristic length are found in the numerator of the (*) Reynolds number. Negative 2m times the angular form of this quantity cross this quantity equals the Coriolis force. Air resistance is proportional to this quantity squared. According to Bernoulli's principle, an increase in this quantity results in a decrease in pressure. For 10 points, name this quantity that equals the rate of change of position and is measured in meters per second.
tossups.answer: velocity [or flow velocity; prompt on u or v; prompt on speed]

tossups.question: This composer's works were cataloged by Jarmil Burghauser. A violent dotted-quarter note B, eighth note C motif played fortissimo by the strings opens the allegro con fuoco final movement of a symphony by this composer. Johannes Brahms introduced this composer to the publisher Fritz Simrock, who commissioned a piece for piano four-hands from them that begins and ends with a furiant. This composer followed their (*) Moravian Duets with a set of dances that, like one of their piano trios, was partially inspired by dumky [DOOM-key]. The largo movement of this composer's E minor ninth symphony borrows a melody from "Swing Low, Sweet Chariot" and was scored in Spillville, Iowa. For 10 points, name this Czech composer of the New World Symphony.
tossups.answer: Antonin Dvorak

tossups.question: An Al Jazeera probe in this sport accused Glenn Maxwell of talking to bookkeepers. After the dismissal of Steven Smith in December 2020, a rule change in this sport allowed the Decision Review System to make more lenient decisions. A 1932-33 international tour of this sport led to criticism of the "bodyline tactic" due to its usage of short-pitched deliveries. This sport is played between England and Australia in the (*) Ashes. Players of this sport include Sachin Tendulkar and Sir Don Bradman, who had a 99.94 Test batting average. This sport is governed by the ICC. For 10 points, name this bat and ball sport played in many British commonwealth countries.
tossups.answer: cricket

tossups.question: One leader with this last name's release from prison is commemorated in a non-American Loyalty Day. The AAA death squad, which supported a leader with this last name, also fought against left-wing supporters of a leader with this last name. The Justicialist party names its ideology after a person with this last name. Left-wing supporters of one person with this last name were killed by snipers in the (*) Ezeiza [ay-SAY-sah] massacre. One person with this last name was overthrown by Jorge Videla, leading to the Dirty War. Supporters of one leader with this last name were known as the "shirtless ones," or descamisados. tossups.answer: Perón [accept Juan Domingo Perón or Isabel Martinez de Perón or Maria Eva Perón or Evita Perón or Peronism]

tossups.question: A poem titled for these animals ends by describing "their hearts of sleeping volcanoes"; that poem repeats the line "she had some [these animals]" and was written by Joy Harjo [HAR-joe]. Another poem named for one of these animals ends with the speaker flying "into the red/Eye, the cauldron of the morning." One of these animals named Ariel titles (*) Sylvia Plath's final collection. In another poem, one of these animals "must think it queer" when the speaker "stop[s] without a farmhouse near". That one of those animals "gives his... bells a shake" to ask "if there is some mistake" in a poem whose speaker has "miles to go before I sleep." For 10 points, the speaker of Robert Frost's "Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening" rides on what animal?
tossups.answer: horses [accept obvious equivalents]

tossups.question: This element, when attached to n-butane, is used to convert dibromoalkenes to alkynes in the 2nd step of the Corey-Fuchs reaction. Hard-soft acid base theory explains why this element's chloride and iodide are soluble in water, but its fluoride is not. In most fusion reactor designs, this element is bombarded with neutrons to produce tritium. This element has a diagonal relationship with magnesium. This element, (*) aluminum, and hydrogen make up a common reducing agent. This is the lightest element to burn red in a flame test. This element's carbonate salt is prescribed to treat bipolar disorder. This metal names a type of ion battery used in cell phones. For 10 points, name this alkali metal with atomic number 3.
tossups.answer: lithium [or Li; accept n-butyllithium or lithium aluminum hydride or lithium-ion battery or lithium carbonate]

tossups.question: An artist most known for their work of this type was featured in a 2020 Microsoft ad for the Hololens 2 before it was pulled due to right-wing backlash. David Bowie's song "Joe the Lion" references a work of this type involving a Volkswagen Beetle titled Trans-Fixed. Another work of this type, Spirit Cooking, which used pigs' blood, gave rise to accusations of Satanism against an artist who is known for these works. That artist placed a rose, a loaded gun, and 70 other objects on a table in a work of this type titled Rhythm 0. Chris (*) Burden is most well known for artworks of this type. The Artist is Present, a work of this type, involved Marina Abramović sitting in silence for over 700 hours. For 10 points, identify this type of art that usually involves an audience and a live presentation by the artist
tossups.answer: performance art [prompt on crucifixion after "Joe the Lion" with "What general type of art was the crucifixion a part of?"; do not accept or prompt on "performing arts"]

tossups.question: Juan Villoro's book Horizontal Vertigo discusses his experiences growing up in this city. A person from this city is referred to as a chilango. Late on September 15, one politician annually rings a bell in this city in the Cry of Dolores. The Angel of Independence and monuments to the Battle of Chapultepec are contained in this city's (*) Paseo de la Reforma. Some chinampas still survive on the outskirts of this city. The original Zócalo was located in this city near the bed of the former Lake Texcoco. For 10 points, name this city formerly known as Tenochtitlan, the capital of the United States's southern neighbor.
tossups.answer: Mexico City [accept Ciudad de México; prompt on Tenochtitlan before mentioned]

bonuses.leadin: Members of this city's namesake school of poetry, like Ted Berrigan and Anne Waldman, helped found the Poetry Project at St. Mark's Church. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this American city, whose namesake school also included Kenneth Koch [coke]. A cultural movement that began in this city included the poet of "Before the Feast of Shushan," Anne Spencer, as well as Langston Hughes.

One member of the New York School, Barbara Guest, wrote a poem partially titled for this Soviet author of "Conversation with Comrade Lenin" and "A Cloud in Trousers." That poem ends with Guest hoping that "tomorrow will be more real, perhaps, / Than yesterday."

In his Fresh Air, Kenneth Koch asks which of this poet "and Mayakovsky, is Jouve of our time?" In a novel by this author, the Bolshevik Strelnikov reveals himself to be Pasha Antipov in a conversation with the title doctor.
answers: New York City [or NYC] [the latter movement is the Harlem Renaissance]
Boris Pasternak [the novel is Doctor Zhivago]

bonuses.leadin: In the third movement of a work for this instrument and flute, the flute must play fast glissandi using the piece's namesake "jet whistle" technique. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this instrument. In the second movement of one work, an orchestra of these instruments accompanies a soprano who lists species of birds and imitates birdsong; that work's first movement sets a poem by Ruth Correa.

This composer wrote Jet Whistle, and included the aforementioned piece for cello orchestra and soprano in a set of nine works inspired by Bach and his home country. His other cello works include the duet Dois Choros (bis) [doyss show-roos beess].

Villa-Lobos' "Divagação" [dee-vah-gah-sow] is a short piece for cello, piano, and optionally one of these instruments. Villa-Lobos' symphonies include a part for timpani, which is one of these instruments.

bonuses.leadin: After one action by this person, the book Fashionable Nonsense was published to criticize central ideas of postmodernism. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this person who duped the journal Social Text into publishing "Transgressing the Boundaries," a fake article that claimed quantum gravity was a social construct.

The Sokal affair was part of the "wars" of this field, in which postmodern intellectuals were accused of denying the effectiveness of this field's namesake method. Hypotheses are tested against evidence in this field.

The Sokal affair has led to greater awareness of studies that do not have this property. Upwards of 50% of highly-cited studies can't be re-confirmed and thus do not have this property, leading to its namesake crisis.
answers: Alan Sokal [accept Sokal affair or Sokal hoax]
science [accept science wars; accept scientific method]
reproducibility [or replicability; accept word forms; accept reproducibility crisis or replication crisis; prompt on verifiability or word forms]

bonuses.leadin: A prime minister of this country known for his aggressive debating style compared the verbal attacks of John Hewson to "being flogged with warm lettuce." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country. This country's prime minister Paul Keating gave the Redfern Park Speech, in which he acknowledged that the government of this former penal colony had harmed Aborigines.
In 1967, this prime minister passed a referendum that counted Aborigines in the population of Australia. This leader later drowned while swimming at Cheviot beach.

Gough [GOFF] Whitlam began the process of returning land deeds to Aboriginal Australians before being removed from power by John Kerr, who held this position. The holder of this position represents the British monarch and technically heads the Australian military.

bonuses.leadin: While the Piola-Kirchhoff tensor expresses this quantity relative to the reference configuration, the Cauchy tensor expresses this quantity relative to the present conformation. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this quantity measured in Pascals. Young's modulus equals this quantity divided by delta L over L.

A version of this physicist's namesake equation states that the stress equals Young's modulus times the strain. For springs, that equation named for this physicist states that force equals negative k times the displacement.
A relativistic generalization of the Cauchy stress tensor is multiplied by 8 pi times big G over c to the fourth power on the right-hand side of these equations.
answers: stress tensor [change in length over original length is the strain]
Einstein field equations [or EFE; prompt on partial]

bonuses.leadin: Herman Sörgel's [ZOOR-ghelz] Atlantropa project was a colonialist plan to build a dam in this location in order to lower the sea level of the Mediterranean. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this location through which the Zanclean flood entered. In antiquity the Pillars of Hercules flanked this location.
The Atlantropa project also included irrigating this desert using water from the Mediterranean. Most of Algeria is covered by this large North African desert.
This strait would have been blocked by a further dam in the Atlantropa project. This strait connects the Mediterranean to the Sea of Marmara.
answers: Dardanelles [accept Strait of Gallipoli or Hellespont]

bonuses.leadin: Bakelite, the first synthetic plastic, was made by reacting this compound with formaldehyde. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this aromatic compound produced in the cumene process by adding a hydroxyl group to benzene.
Phenol is a stronger acid than other alcohols because its conjugate base is stabilized by this phenomenon. In this phenomenon, a single molecule has more than one possible Lewis structure.
The deprotonation of phenol produces a compound with this many resonance structures. This many carbons are present in one molecule of pentane.
answers: phenol [or carbolic acid; prompt on C6H5OH or C6H6O]
resonance [or mesomerism; accept electron delocalization or charge delocalization]

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, name the following about artists who have used their work to defy gender norms:
parts: A thermometer, cuttlefish bone, and several marble cubes appear in a sculpture by this artist asking this artist's female alter ego "Why Not Sneeze, Rose Sélavy?" Another work by this artist put a mustache on the Mona Lisa

This gender non-conforming Surrealist photographer is best known for their self-portraits, created along with their partner Marcel Moore. In one photograph, this artist appears with hearts on their face and wearing a jersey asking the viewer not to kiss them
Both Cahun and Duchamp were from this country. The original Mona Lisa is in this country's Louvre Museum

bonuses.leadin: This attack was launched from Tinian airfield in the recently-captured Mariana Islands and given the designation "Special Mission 13." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this airstrike, executed by the Enola Gay, which was followed three days later by a similar strike on the city of Nagasaki.
This bomb was dropped on Hiroshima by the Enola Gay. This uranium-235 weapon had a smaller blast yield than Fat Man, which was dropped on Nagasaki.

This Portland-class heavy cruiser was sunk after delivering the Little Boy to Tinian. The sinking of this ship was the largest loss of life from a single ship in the history of the U.S. Navy, partly due to her mission being confidential.

bonuses.leadin: In a long monologue, this character asks questions such as "Does the trees moving make the wind blow?" and "Why are oranges round?" For 10 points each:
parts: Name this character. In the short story in which this character appears, he is kidnapped by Bill and Sam, who end up paying a $250 ransom to return him.
This author wrote "The Ransom of Red Chief," which features one of their characteristic twist endings. They also wrote "The Gift of the Magi."

O. Henry's story "The Last Leaf" centers on Johnsy, a pneumonia-stricken member of this profession. In another story, a member of this profession follows a dark-haired woman to a brothel while his friend chases Schiller's wife.
answers: the Red Chief [accept descriptions such as Ebenezer Dorset's son, or the annoying kid from "The Ransom of Red Chief," accept Johnny Dorset; prompt on Dorset]
an artist [or a painter] [the latter story is Gogol's "Nevsky Prospekt"]

bonuses.leadin: Two days before his death, this politician nominated Ariel Henry to succeed Claude Joseph as prime minister. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this recently-assassinated Haitian president who received criticism for attempting to increase his own power through constitutional referendums.
Mercenaries from this country, who were supposedly recruited by CTU, have been detained because of the attack on Moïse. This country is currently led by Iván Duque [du-kay] Márquez.
Previously, a magnitude 7.0 one of these events had caused great upheaval in Haiti. That one of these natural events near Port-au-Prince was followed by a cholera outbreak.
answers: Republic of Colombia [accept República de Colombia]

bonuses.leadin: The "parabolic" type of these structures form when their tops are anchored by vegetation. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these mounds of sand that form due to wind. They are common in deserts.

Winds can cause sand to "bounce" up the front of a dune in this type of motion contrasted with creep. Streams transport pebbles through this type of motion, where particles are lifted up for short periods of time.
In some closed basins like in White Sands National Park, dunes may form out of this water-soluble mineral. This mineral has a Mohs hardness of two and is composed of calcium sulfate dihydrate.

bonuses.leadin: This author described the duende ("doo-ehn-DAY") as an artistic force that "works on the dancer's body like wind on sand" in their lecture "Theory and Play of the Duende." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this gay Spanish playwright and poet whose Rural Trilogy includes Yerma and The House of Bernarda Alba.

Lorca claimed that this Spanish Golden Age author's duende, along with that of Cervantes, "crown[s] the altarpiece of Spain's duende." This founder of the conceptismo movement and author of El Buscon branded a rival a "cardsharp" and a "swordfish with an awful beard."

In the lecture, Lorca describes how a member of this profession that is "bitten by the duende" "gives a lesson in Pythagorean music." Lorca wrote a "Lament for the Death of a" member of this profession, Ignacio Sánchez Mejías.

bonuses.leadin: This dictator's lavish coronation cost more than his country's annual budget, partially leading to his downfall. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Napoleon-obsessed African dictator who was overthrown in 1979. Valery Giscard D'Estaing [ZEES-card dest-AUNG] was an ally of this dictator before he was accused of cannibalism.

Despite being involved in the coup, Giscard D'Estaing lost his 1981 reelection bid due to a scandal where he received two of these objects from Bokassa. Charles Taylor supported the RUF in Sierra Leone in exchange for "blood" examples of these objects.
French support for Jean-Bédel Bokassa may have been due to Bokassa's service with the Free French Forces in this war. During this war, Bokassa was deployed to recapture Algeria from Hitler's Germany.
answers: Jean-Bédel Bokassa [or Bokassa I or Salah Eddine Ahmed Bokassa]
diamonds [accept diamonds affair or conflict diamonds or red diamonds or brown diamonds or hot diamonds]
World War II [or WW2 or Second World War]

bonuses.leadin: An edible one of these animals called the sea pineapple reportedly tastes like "rubber dipped in ammonia." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this subphylum of filter-feeding chordates that includes salps and sea squirts. These animals possess a namesake covering made of cellulose.
Tunicate larvae are named for their resemblance to this larval stage of amphibians. These aquatic larvae grow lungs and limbs as they metamorphose into adult frogs or salamanders.

A class of tunicates called larvaceans [lar-VAY-see-inz] use "houses" made of this substance to filter food from seawater. In humans, this substance is produced by goblet cells on membranes in the respiratory tract.
answers: Tunicata [or tunicates; accept Urochordata or urochordates]
mucus [accept mucus houses or mucous membranes]

bonuses.leadin: John 11:35 famously states that "Jesus wept" shortly before he resurrected this person. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this person, a brother of Mary and Martha who was resurrected by Jesus after he arrived in Galilee four days late.
Jesus healed a bleeding woman before he raised this man's daughter from the dead in the Synoptic Gospels. Jesus says "Little girl, get up" in order to raise this man's daughter from the dead.

Later in the New Testament, this saint resurrects a man named Eutychus [YOO-tick-us] who had fallen out of a window after falling asleep. This missionary authored several Epistles after being blinded on a trip to Damascus

bonuses.leadin: Carl Randall created a series of paintings depicting modern locations along this road. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this road whose "Fifty-Three Stations" are depicted in a popular ukiyo-e print series by Hiroshige

Several fishermen are depicted in a boat during this phenomenon at Tsuchiyama in that series. This phenomenon is shown as thin, slanted black lines in a different Hiroshige print where people on a footbridge carry umbrellas to protect themselves from it

This artist based his painting Bridge in the Rain off of Hiroshige's print of a sudden rainshower over a bridge. This artist also depicted a man resting his head on his hand in his Portrait of Dr. Gachet
answers: Tōkaidō [accept The Fifty-Three Stations of the Tōkaidō]

bonuses.leadin: The lead singer of this band sarcastically claimed that they broke up after the release of their album This is Happening to sell more tickets. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this dance-punk band fronted by James Murphy that reunited in 2016 to release American Dream. A 2013 Stereogum piece called this band's song "All My Friends" a "celebration of paradoxes" that defines the millennium.
LCD Soundsystem released a non-silent composition entitled 45:33 in 2006, the title of which was a reference to this minimalist composer's notoriously silent 4:33.

LCD Soundsystem's song "Losing My Edge" satirically claims that, among other absurd statements, the singer "woke up naked on a beach in [this island] in 1988." A 2015 hit for Mike Posner describes taking a pill in this tourist destination in the Balearic Islands.
answers: Ibiza [or Eivissa; accept "I Took a Pill in Ibiza"]

bonuses.leadin: In the article "How To Write About [this country]," four authors from this country insist that "fundamentalist mangoes must have more texture; secular mangoes should have artificial flavoring." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country. That article proposes that authors from this country ask their "genius mad uncles" to translate poets like Hasan Dars from this country's national language, Urdu. This country was the home of Malala Yousafzai.

"How To Write About Pakistan" was partially written by this Pakistani author, whose novel The Reluctant Fundamentalist begins with Changez quipping, "Do not be frightened by my beard: I am a lover of America."

In another Hamid novel, the lovers Saeed and Nadia escape through a series of magical doors to this general location. In a novel titled for this general location, the idiotic Pigsy kills demons with a nine-toothed iron rake.
answers: the West [accept Exit West or Journey To The West]

bonuses.leadin: Prior to this battle, Pope Innocent III issued a proclamation of crusade in response to Alfonso VIII's defeat at Alarcos. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this 13th century battle, considered a major turning point in the Reconquista. A Christian coalition defeated the Almohad Caliphate led by al-Nasir at this battle.
The Battle of Las Navas de Tolosa was fought in this country, which was unified with Aragon in 1469 to form Spain. This historic country bordered Portugal.

In the Battle of Las Navas de Tolosa, Sancho the Strong of this kingdom led forces in the right wing. This kingdom in the Pyrenees was located between Castile and Aragon and would later be ruled by Henry IV.
answers: Battle of Las Navas de Tolosa [or Battle of Al-Uqab]
Kingdom of Navarre [accept Kingdom of Pamplona]
